summary: WSJ: Award-winning business & markets coverage, breaking news & global headlines

scraped_reviews.content: The last update broke the app on Android. Half of the time I select an article, the app goes into a forwarding loop, jumping from the initial page to the selected article, then back to the initial page and so on. the only way to stop this is to minimize the app then close it. As a result, I'm unable to read many of the articles and unable to use the app. Please address!

Why is it so hard to build a reader app? Offline mode doesn't work for most articles, because the app loads them in a web view. If you lock the screen while reading an article and then unlock the screen, the app will force a reload of the article your were reading. This is fine if you are on a good network connection, as it will take a second or two. However when you are on a poor network it can take a minute. Poor design choice. Edit: Deducting a star for constantly having to sign in

The cost for WSJ is out-of-family high compared with other quality journalism. I expect a phenomenal app, and this one isn't it. Unhappy that I receive notifications to read articles that I've already read. That's an easy one to fix. Unhappy that I can't seem to find settings to fine-tune data usage. Something that possibly only downloads the text without photos. Or downloads article intros but I can pick and choose what to load. Happy with "today's paper" and "next article" features.

I've been subscribed for 7 months now, I love reading the finance news and find the reporting on a higher caliber. The app can still use improvement on many fronts, for instance the way it connects to the web, some articles will just take you online which sucks, I have an app because I want an app version! The search engine is pretty inaccurate, I don't get why it won't just return any keyword, simply by c/p the headline. I should be able to find anything by searching a word or 2.

STILL haven't fixed the DAILY sign-in issue. Pretty pissed. I need to sign in on the same device nearly every day. WTH? Also, when I save an article on my phone, that action does not sync to my tablet. One of my main reasons for wanting to save the article on my phone is to read it more comfortably later on my tablet! Also, what is the point of having a share button in the app if it does not unlock the article for non-subscribers to read?

The app is alright. It scrolls well and searching by byline goes about as well as one can hope, meaning not well at all. The gripe that led to this review is that articles have a random chance of opening not in the app, but through the in-app web browser. When this happens, there's no option to save articles and sometimes I am prompted to subscribe/login to read the article, which takes me back to the app which then opens the article online and so the article remains unread. Unacceptable.

I signed up for a three month introductory offer but was charged full price after the first month. Checked my account, Surprise! There's no billing history, or plan breakdown, or indication of upcoming payment schedule. You can't even unsubscribe online, it isn't even among the menu options, you have to google to find the phone number. Also, why send notifications for an article and not have that notification bring you to the actual article?

The app is well designed and easy to use. However, I need to log-in every time I click to read an article that pops up as a notification. It's a bit dumb that a news app would require you to consistently log back on. It's like if Outlook on your phone would require you to enter your log-in every time you wanted to check an email. I'm actually considering unsubscribing to be honest.

Buggie, stories often don't load or open. No other app install/reinstall/clear cache/force stop as this app. And it is required multiple times of day. Also, WSJ is militant in limiting the # of logins you can have on devices, so you are constantly having to re-login. A greedy, anti-consumer company, so they make you jump thru all sorts "verification" checks when you first subscribe. For the cost of a subscription to WSJ, you would expect much better.

Updated: Had a subscription price hike and I wasn't notified until after I was charged for the first month. No way to cancel the subscription online or in-app. Have to wait until business hours to cancel via phone call. Original: Good objective news for the most part. They did a visual redesign sometime ago that made it harder to find what you want so thats inconvenient, but not unusable.

The app needs a lot of improvements. The notification links don't launch the app. Instead, keep asking to sign in to the account. At times, the app launches embedded browser and requires signing again. It's annoying and painful, especially when users don't keep the cookies and passwords stored in the browser. Daily Newspaper download, and other content is good though.

They have eliminated the option to see the full paper. None of the pricing is available. This only shows the articles and, because you don't see the full paper, I have no idea if the application provides all the articles. Considering my local paper does provide that information for well under half the annual price of the WSJ I am very disappointed. However, they solve the weird thing of making you hunt down the full article which I used to have to do before the "upgrade".

The app is fine. The reporting?Inconsistent, and as biased and needlessly inflammatory at times--like all the others. Please note, I, and many others, hate when we are forced to call a sales office to cancel, suspend, or otherwise deal with a subscription bought through the app. It serves only as an intentional barrier. As soon as I learned this was the case, I made the call and cancelled. Permanently.

This app is very weak. It claims it downloads overnight and keeps 7 days of issues. However, if you try to access that without WiFi you will find that they mostly don't exist. You will need a wifi connection to get most articles and virtually all pictures. Just experienced this on an international flight. Has been an issue for multiple years and many complaints from their users but they don't want to fix it for some reason, or they don't know how.

Was a good app. The May 29 update doesn't work . It logged me out and taping log in just blinks the screen and nothing happens. Haven't been able to login since. The app is a data hog compared to other papers. Another fault is it always wants to be logged in. You can't download and read off line ex. Read during a flight is not possible without a wifi connection.

Overall the app is good and the content is better than most. However the subscription plan is frustrating. I subscribed for one price then one year later the price doubles and I had to call (can't cancel online) and "do the dance" and threaten to cancel. Then they offered a lower price, limited time. I am tired of have to call every year and beg.

WSJ is my preferred news source, but starting a few months ago, it can't seem to regularly recognize me as a subscriber. As a result, I often have to login before reading an article that I receive email and Android-driven notices about. Articles pop up with just a paragraph or two and an annoying watermark that says content isn't available right now. However, it always is after I relog in. Tech support says to uninstall and reinstall the app, but that makes no difference.

Deceptive pricing practices. Signed up for a year at a discounted rate for their bundle, after a year the same low rate continues. A few months after the year I stopped checking and a few months after that I'm suddenly hit with a nearly 9x increase in price of $50. I get alerts on my card so I request refund within an hour of the charge and they refused.

this app gets you the news you need, but they could do such a better job with it. the sign in is really messed up. everytime I want to read a story on my phone, I have to sign in. if I want to read another article after finishing one, it sometimes asks me to log in all over again. I have several other apps that can manage to save my login credentials without me having to login this frequently, and I wish I could say the same about the wsj app. messages to the dev team are unhelpful.

Updated on 10/8/18. The app now crashes every time I try to read a story. The update just made it worse! The app stopped working for me. I'm a subscriber but after the latest update the app reports that I'm logged in but will not allow me to enter a login. I called. They say they are aware of the problem. But it's been a month and no change. Just give us the old version that worked username (email)

I have had an online subscription to the WSJ for fifteen years. I'm about to drop it. With every other app on my phone, I only have to log into the app ONCE, when I set up a new phone. The WSJ app consistently and persistently forgets logins, requiring me to log in over and over again. It is very annoying and unacceptable. The FT app remembers my login -- I'm about to switch to FT full time.

I like WSJ's content, but the app itself is barely functional. Clicking on a banner notification tries to open the article in a browser instead of in the app. Clicking on an article link elsewhere also opens in a browser instead of the app. Searching by byline sometimes works and sometimes doesn't, and you can't click on a byline in an article to see what else that person has written. I am also regularly unable to find articles using the app search bar, especially newer articles.

I can't find an option to unsubscribe ANYWHERE. I can subscribe. Renew. But not cancel. Further, it states that my subscription has expired. YET, it's been withdrawing subscription fees. In addition, it doesn't recognize any of my identifying info as being valid - but, I'm able to log in, and my name pops up on the app and website. Seems pretty shady. I'll try calling customer service next week.

Overallall the app is good. I like the embedded videos along with the latest news and editorials. The one annoying thing that occurs numerous times while reading the articles is that when an article is closed, the screen reverts back to the beginning of the list of articles instead of to where the article that was just closed is located. One then has to scroll through what can be a long list to get back to where one was. A list of available videos would be nice.

The articles are great, but the app keeps signing me out and you have to put in your password all the time. This would not be much of an issue, except it happens when the app notifications are on and they lead you to click on the link and then somehow you are not logged in so you have to enter your password again. Annoying! If you're going to notify me of an article, then make sure you have my credentials or don't notify me

I'm only using the app because mobile wsj pages include an element that makes mobile chrome unusable. For some stupid reason the wsj app doesn't allow you to reach the comments section of the articles. If you're the wsj and don't want to have a comment section, then get rid of it. But if you're going to have it make it part of the app experience. And fix your damned website.

The constant logins are beyond irritating. If I open the app from a notification I'm asked to login. It typically takes at least 3 tries before I can read the article I'm interested in. Sometimes no amount of logins will remove the paywall banner. The other thing I don't like is you are unable to comment on stories. You can comment on certain stories from a web browser. Other than these issues it's a pretty good app. These issues take it from 5 to 3 stars.

Subscribed to Digital All Access at a promotional rate of $19.49. At end of promo period I called to cancel rather than pay full rate and they begged me to continue by offering to extend me at 19.99. What they didn't tell me is that they were going to switch me to Digital Lite, which is a deficient product that blocks you from using their Application on all platforms. A dirty trick.

Latest update 4/23/22 the app bumps me out of some articles I am in the middle of reading. When I try to re-open the article or any article it just shows the circular reloading arrow and does not load. I have to shut down the app and re-open it to finally be able to load an article. WSJ app os one of the worst apps in terms of issues after updates. Many times it crashes after reading an article for a short period of time forcing a restart.
scraped_reviews.replyContent: We apologize for this issue. A fix is being released as we speak. Thank you for reporting.

scraped_reviews.content: Borderline perfect, the only issue is that sometimes when you go back to the home screen while you're reading an article, and you switch back to the app, it acts like you're not signed in. To fix it you can just hit back once and go right back into your article and you dont actually have to sign in. Otherwise, the app is fast, well organized, and very easy to use. That said; I'm using a flagship phone so I dont know how well the app performs on other devices.

The Wall Street Journal is not cheap. For the coat of a subscription, we should get a much better app than this. If left open in the background, it invariably drops your session, forcing you to log back in. There are often links to stories on the WSJ website, which, when clicked, prompt you again for login credentials. Etc. A clumsy experience, overall. At a premium price, to boot.

There is almost always a message telling me there was an error loading an article, even when the article successfully loads. The messages is imposed over the article as I scroll, which makes it annoying as I scroll through. I also am not a fan of how the sections are organized. Glad I only played $1 for a two month trial. MSN Money is way better.

Still a terrible app. It won't keep me signed-in on my tablet. I get logged out after each article and sometimes, the login just doesn't take. It doesn't reject my credentials - it just doesn't give me access. This doesn't happen on my phone. Also, this app is a bloated storage hog. I can't find a setting to stop it from amassing 1 GB of downloaded content. Every few months, I have to uninstall and reinstall the app to clear out the data - can't find another way.

Multiple typos daily. It's okay. I like the paper. My problems with the app are as follows. First, no tabbed browsing. I like being able to go through and open tabs for what I'm going to read, then go back when I have time and read them all. Second, The editorials are definitely far right, which I would expect from Murdoch, but I wish the editorial board would try to be more diverse. Third, ads. Why are there ads in a paid only app? Also, the number of anti-vax ads is alarming.
scraped_reviews.replyContent: Thank you kindly for your considered feedback. It is greatly appreciated and duly noted. We hope to offer continued improvements in all these areas.

scraped_reviews.content: Longtime subscriber. Paper layout has improved and become easier to read on mobile. HOWEVER, a few unbelievablly annoying bugs still exist that I must deduct stars for: 1. If you are reading news from ANY other source that contains a WSJ link tapping the link does NOT bring you to your logged in app- you are taken to a mobile sign in page-every freaking time. 2. Graphs, charts and tables are many times useless. There is no zoom capabalites so unless you have bionic eyes you're not getting to understand the data. 3. Offline reading still NOT possible. If you get on a airplane a few articles are readable but in short order you receive "no internet connection is available" and the app becomes useless. I have gone over the settings carefully and there is no way to address this. 3 star rating for what easily could be a 5 star experiance.

Would leave 0 stars if that were possible. Have never been able to get the app to allow me to sign in, even after following every piece of advice about re-installing, device configuration, etc. Absolute trash app if you have to work that hard just to sign into it. I have no issues signing into WSJ on my desktop via web browser, so the app is definitely the problem.

I have an app-only subscription. The major problem is that the app opens some of the stories in the browser instead of continuing in the app. This situation has improved over the year in that recently I've been able to read many of these without browser warnings about using up my free views for the month. Some articles still open in the browser and tell me to subscribe. Often they are the popular/ interesting ones and I'm miffed to be excluded.

To read stories, you have to be a subscriber. I have entered my subscription information. If I switch to a different app, I come back to a notice that I have to be a subscriber to read the rest of the article. If I am, I must login again. I've found out that all I need to do is go back to the section and reopen the article ... at the beginning. I have notified support to no avail. A 30+ year subscription history may end because of this ... and their inability to help me.

The app frequently doesn't remember me, and i need to sign in repeatedly.. Sometimes it hangs up or crashes during sign in process. Also, i dislike that articles can't be saved to Pocket for TTS. Otherwise the app functions similarly to other news apps. Just unacceptable to have major IT problems when paying a significant amount for a subscription (more than other subscriptions), and for a product devoted largely to business and technology journalism.

Half of the articles I can't open, with the error "Application error: a client-side exception has occurred (see the browser console for more information)." in black text on a white background. Maybe it is because of my VPN, something I will not turn off on public wifi. I am certain the writers of WSJ can emphathize. Please fix this, so I can read the articles I am paying a subscription to read. Thank you

This app never works for me. Always signs me out. I sign back in and still cannot access full articles. I pay every month and get zero service. After a long wait on the phone I spoke with the representative who told me to uninstall and reinstall the app. This Nintendo 64-style solution proved to be short lived, and I am still unable to access full length articles. Having to uninstall and reinstall the app to read one article is completely unacceptable.

Never received one delivery of the actual paper, despite paying for the print and digital subscription. They charge your account days before the actual renewal date, and don't refund any renewal. The cancellation process is aggravating. It took me 20 minutes, and I had to call and listen to somebody give me offer after offer when I really just wanted to cancel. The actual stories and reporting were just fine. It's similar to any other reputable news source, just way more aggravating.

Be very careful of this service. The review is not about the quality of the articles or editorials as that would be subjective. This one is for their shady trade practices. They will lure you in with a good promo and have you on autorenewal once that promo expires. No receipts or subscription renewal notifications are sent to your email. There is no way to cancel the subscription through the app and the only way to do it is by calling customer service so if you're busy you'll often put it off.

The WSJ app never works, which makes my subscription a total waste of money since I'm rarely on my desktop PC when I need to access articles. Every time I click a WSJ article in Twitter, the app gives me nothing but the spinning arrow. The only way I can get to an article is by searching for it in a web browser, so I usually have to give up rather than waste time trying to find it that way. WSJ is the only one of dozens of apps/links I have this issue with so it is definitely the app.

Like WSJ articles. Most are well written and most are not slanted. I'll take that over all the other opinionated publishers nowadays. My fret is with the non ability to comment in the app as a member. What's the deal WSJ?!?! You lose one star for that. If you at least had the option to open the article in the browser from the app to comment on that would be great! Another star for that. Pick up your game and learn to support your readers requests. You're failing in this market to do so.

Confusing difference between content accessibility depending on subscription type. I can access most, but not all. I was told I would need a different digital description. Very aggravating. Also, the app frequently just returns to the top of the page, loosing your place and forcing you to scroll down to where you were. Other news apps simply inform you that an update is available and let you decide when to refresh.

Reading/page formats are different for each device.....phone, tablet, lap top.....very confusing. On tablet the app frequently stops working during reading, usually around the opinion, business sections requiring closing and reopen the app.....very annoying. Delivery of the product is no where near the journalism professionalism. Have been a reader since 1955....about 64 years.

This app needs a lot of work. It will refresh and take me to the top of the feed without prompt, making me scroll through dozens of stories to get back to my place. After clicking on some of the stories I am prompted to sign in to read them, which I have obviously already done to read the paper. Ridiculous that the app is this bad considering they are shifting to digital deliveries

Five stars as a news source, but the mobile app is a sad afterthought. Sometimes when I click an article from my notification, it paywalls me and I have to relogin, even though I'm logged into the app and using it. Second, the share button is worthless. For real? I can share full articles while logged in on the web, but can't do the same from the app?? Disappointing. If I didn't enjoy the notifications, I would use the web. Please pay attention to the app, or you'll lose digital subscribers.

Articles that WSJ posts on other apps (e.g. LinkedIn, Snap) do not let you read unless you sign in to account with subscription. Signing into account sends you to the WSJ app, but not the article. Searching for the article on the app does not yield results. What's the point in posting an article that you can't read even with a paid subscription? what am I paying for? Crossword feature is ridiculous. Huge static keyboard blocks most of the puzzle, no option to hide it. Canceling subscription.
